message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of catatonia, which can be caused by fluoxetine. Lorazepam is a common treatment for catatonia. Benztropine and Haloperidol are not first-line treatments for catatonia, and electroconvulsive therapy is reserved for severely impaired individuals who are unresponsive to other treatments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of catatonia, which can be a side effect of fluoxetine. Lorazepam is the best initial therapy for catatonia. Benztropine is used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms, electroconvulsive therapy is a more invasive treatment option, and haloperidol is not recommended as it can worsen symptoms in patients with catatonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is displaying symptoms of catatonia, which can occur as a side effect of antidepressant medications. Lorazepam is the preferred initial therapy for catatonia. Benztropine is used for extrapyramidal side effects caused by antipsychotic medications. Electroconvulsive therapy and haloperidol may be considered if the patient does not respond to lorazepam.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest catatonia, which can be caused by serotonin syndrome from the switch in antidepressants. The initial therapy should be lorazepam to treat the symptoms. Benztropine and haloperidol are not appropriate in this situation, and electroconvulsive therapy would be a last resort if lorazepam does not improve the patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest catatonia, and the patient’s medical history raises suspicion for medication-induced catatonia. Lorazepam is the first-line treatment for catatonia, and it has been shown to rapidly improve symptoms in up to 80% of cases. Benztropine is used for extrapyramidal symptoms, which are not present. Electroconvulsive therapy may be considered for refractory cases but is not the initial therapy. Haloperidol may worsen symptoms in patients with catatonia.

Electroconvulsive therapy may also be used, but it is not the best initial therapy. Antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, may worsen symptoms, so they should be used with caution. Benztropine is not indicated for the treatment of catatonia.
